definition:
A *Euclidean domain* is an integral domain on which a Euclidean
valuation can be defined.

Every Euclidean domain is a principal ideal domain, and therefore also a
unique factorization domain.

Any two elements of a Euclidean domain have a greatest common divisor,
which can be computed using the Euclidean algorithm.

An example of a Euclidean domain is the ring ${\mathbb{Z}}$. Another
example is the polynomial ring $F[x]$, where $F$ is any field. Every
field is also a Euclidean domain.
